II. 1 The same distinction is made by Marcellus speaking to the Senate: by Aristotle, when he says that slavery, though lawful, may be unjust: by the Thebans in Thucydides.

2 So the Roman jurists, though they speak of the right of cap- tivsty, also call this right a wrong, injuria. So Seneca. So Livy says the Italians were obstinate in injury‚ because they retained what they had in war taken from the Syracusans. So Dio Prusaeensis speaks of captives taken in war, as unjustly enslaved.
